fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Rapid wilting, often starting on one side. A key sign is a dark brown to black lesion at the base of the stalk extending upwards from the soil line. When the stalk is split, the pith shows separated, brown-to-black disks. Roots become black and rotten.

prevention: Use resistant cultivars.
Form high and wide beds to provide drainage for root systems, as the fungus is favored by high soil moisture.
Use balanced fertilization; avoid excessive levels of nitrogen.
Control nematodes as they can greatly exacerbate disease severity and reduce the effectiveness of resistant varieties.
Practice crop rotation with any other crop to prevent build-up of the inoculum in the soil, as the fungus primarily attacks tobacco.
monitoring: Monitor from the seedling stage for symptoms: wilting, yellowing of leaves, stem lesions, and plant death.
Check for root and crown rot.
Look for stems that are dark brown or black near the soil line.
Inspect the stem pith for dry, brown-to-black, plate-like discs.
Once the fungus is detected, practice at least a 2-year rotation. The longer the rotation, the more effective the control.
Survey tobacco fields and keep track of disease pressure, incidence, and severity every year.
direct_control: Practice field sanitation: destroy stalks and roots immediately following harvest.
Apply Metalaxyl-M/Mefenoxam where registered and appropriate.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: On young plants, leaves may cup downwards and become stunted. On older plants, distinct yellow to light green spots appear on the upper leaf surface. In cool, humid conditions, the underside of these spots is covered with a dense, bluish-gray, downy fungal growth.

prevention: Use resistant varieties whenever possible.
Orient fields and rows to maximize air circulation and sunlight penetration to promote leaf drying.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, which can lead to dense, susceptible canopies.
Destroy tobacco stalks, roots, and volunteer seedlings immediately after harvest to reduce overwintering sites for the pathogen.
Maintain proper plant spacing to reduce canopy humidity.
monitoring: Begin scouting early in the season, especially during cool, wet, and cloudy weather.
Check the undersides of leaves for the characteristic bluish-gray mold, particularly in the lower canopy.
Monitor regional alerts and forecasts, as blue mold spores can travel long distances on wind currents.
Pay close attention to low-lying or shaded areas of the field where humidity remains high.
direct_control: Apply preventative fungicides before the disease is established, especially when weather conditions are favorable for infection.
Once detected, apply systemic fungicides according to label recommendations to manage the spread.
Promptly harvest mature leaves to salvage them before they become infected.
In greenhouses, increase temperature and decrease humidity to create an unfavorable environment for the pathogen.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Affects lower, mature leaves, inducing small wet spots that become brown and circular, with concentric rings and a chlorotic halo. A black, velvet-like conidial layer may appear on spots in humid conditions. Lesions can also appear on stems and petioles.

prevention: Use fungus-free seeds.
Avoid re-establishing a crop in a plot where the disease has been severe.
Provide balanced fertiliser (not excessive in nitrogen, adequate potash and phosphate).
Reduce planting density to promote ventilation.
Control bud removing and root-knot nematodes.
Use resistant varieties if available.
monitoring: Monitor lower, mature leaves for small wet spots that turn into brown, circular lesions with concentric rings and a yellow halo.
Check for a black, velvet-like conidial layer on spots in humid conditions.
Look for lesions on stems and petioles.
direct_control: Do not crush and bury remaining plant parts in the field after harvest.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Lesions are small (2-15 mm), circular, with a reddish-brown margin and a necrotic, parchment-like center. Minute black dots (fruiting bodies) are scattered in the center. Spots occur mostly on lower, mature leaves.

prevention: Use only healthy and disease-free seeds.
Sterilize and prepare soil properly.
Carefully inspect seedlings and discard infected ones before transplanting.
Eliminate weed-host reservoirs around tobacco fields.
Use balanced fertilization; avoid excess nitrogen.
Rotate with a non-host crop.
monitoring: Monitor all plant stages from nursery to curing.
Look for characteristic frog-eye lesions (2-15 mm) with reddish-brown margins and white centers.
Check for minute black dots in the center of lesions.
Focus on lower leaves, as mature leaves are more susceptible.
Note that spots can also occur on younger leaves in wet weather.
direct_control: Remove crop residues prior to planting a new crop.
Bury infected tobacco stalks and roots deeply.
Apply appropriate botanical fungicides like Timorex Gold following label instructions.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Rapid wilting, often on one side of the plant, sometimes with yellowing. The entire plant eventually wilts and dies. The stalk becomes dark at the ground level, and vascular tissues show yellow-brown discoloration and dark streaks. Roots may turn brown to black.

prevention: In fields with a history of the disease, use varieties with high resistance.
Wash and steam-sterilize greenhouse trays.
Select warm, well-drained sites for plant beds and prepare high, wide beds.
Avoid root wounding and manage nematodes.
Use balanced fertilization, avoiding excessive nitrogen.
Control other host plants (e.g., Ragweed) in and around the field.
Disinfect tools and equipment regularly.
Practice long crop rotations with non-hosts like fescue, soybean, or small grains. Avoid rotation with potato, tomato, pepper, or groundnut.
monitoring: Monitor plant beds regularly for symptoms.
Look for initial signs of one-sided foliar wilting.
Check the stalk for darkening at the ground level and discoloration of vascular tissues.
Inspect roots for browning or blackening.
direct_control: Destroy stalks and roots immediately at the end of the harvest.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: May cause brown, moist and soft lesions on the stem of the plants at the soil line. Roots may also be affected, turning light brown and their cortex eventually disintegrates. Symptoms include browning and death of many feeder roots and decay of the root cortex, the taproot and the buried portion of the stem. Foliar lesions may also be observed on the lower leaves.

prevention: Limit early irrigations and provide maximum ventilation in nurseries.
Use a healthy or disinfected substrate.
Do not mix sand or soil from a field with the substrate.
Place plugs on a plastic film, not directly on the floor.
Avoid setting tobacco seedlings in very wet or cold soils.
Pay attention to the quality of irrigation water.
monitoring: Monitor for brown, moist and soft lesions on the stem at the soil line.
Check for browning and death of roots.
Look for foliar lesions on lower leaves.
direct_control: Treat the entire substrate solution with an anti-oomycete fungicide.
Apply fungicide at the collar level of the plants by thoroughly soaking the soil if symptoms appear during the growing season.
Remove infected plants quickly from the nurseries.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Symptoms vary but include mottling or mosaic patterns (interveinal yellowing, vein banding), abnormal leaf shape (blisters, filiform shape, curling), and localized rusty brown necrotic lesions. Widespread necrosis can destroy the terminal bud.

prevention: Control aphids, the primary vector.
Protect nurseries and young plants with agrotextiles.
Keep nurseries and fields free of weeds, which can be reservoir hosts.
Practice timely topping and good sucker control to make plants less attractive to aphids.
Apply nitrogen fertilizers at recommended rates; avoid over-fertilizing.
Avoid transplanting near affected areas.
Plant natural barriers of non-susceptible crops (e.g., maize) around the field.
monitoring: Monitor for both aphids and virus symptoms weekly, especially early in the season.
Look for mosaic patterns, abnormal leaf shapes, and necrotic lesions.
Apply control measures for aphids as soon as they are seen in the field.
direct_control: If infections are detected early in nurseries, eliminate plants with CMV symptoms immediately.
Use yellow sticky traps to attract and kill winged aphids.
Topping can help reduce aphid populations.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Symptoms vary by strain and cultivar. Includes various discoloration patterns like mottling, vein yellowing (clearing), vein banding (greener areas along veins), and chlorotic rings on middle leaves. Leaves can be small, crinkled, and curled.

prevention: Use resistant varieties.
Protect nurseries and young plants from aphids using non-woven fabrics.
Avoid planting tobacco next to PVY-susceptible crops like potato, tomato, and pepper.
Control weeds in and around nurseries to eliminate virus sources.
Control aphid populations in plant beds using sticky traps and reflective surfaces.
monitoring: Monitor for various patterns of discoloration (mottling, vein clearing, vein banding, chlorotic rings).
Look for small, crinkled, and curled leaves.
direct_control: In the nursery, infected plants should be destroyed quickly and not transplanted.
For vector management, refer to aphid control measures.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Disease Name: Damping-off, Collar cankers, Leaf spot (Target Spot)
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Causes damping-off in nurseries, with water-soaked lesions on the stem at soil line that turn brown and girdle the collar. In the field, it causes reddish-brown cankers on the stem. On leaves, it causes wet, circular spots that show wide concentric patterns and a chlorotic halo. The centre of the spots may fall out, leaving holes.

prevention: Control greenhouse climate to avoid excessive moisture and high temperature.
Ensure nitrogen fertilisation is not too low.
Use healthy potting media in the nursery.
Disinfect soil in traditional nurseries.
Use plastic film to separate mini-clods from the soil.
Consider soil solarization.
Avoid high planting densities.
Drain heavy and wet soils.
Ensure balanced fertilisation.
monitoring: Monitor for damping-off in nurseries.
Check for reddish-brown cankers on stems in the field.
Look for circular leaf spots with concentric patterns and a chlorotic halo.
direct_control: Remove plant debris at the end of each clipping in the greenhouse.
Sanitise trays where infected seedlings were grown.
Do not transplant diseased seedlings.
Remove lower leaves in the field.
Apply registered fungicides like Azoxystrobin to control target spot in the field.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Wildfire appears as small, pale-green leaf spots that become necrotic with a wide yellow halo. Angular Leaf Spot lesions are necrotic and angular in shape, lacking the halo. Young leaves may be deformed and twisted.

prevention: Use certified seed and resistant cultivars.
Change nursery locations or sterilize seedbeds with steam.
Provide ditches around seedbeds to prevent runoff contamination.
Keep the area free of alternate hosts like solanaceous weeds.
Ventilate nurseries to reduce moisture.
Avoid sprinkler irrigation and working with wet plants.
Use balanced fertilization (avoid excessive nitrogen, low potassium, high pH).
Rotate with non-susceptible crops.
Sterilize clipping tools regularly.
Destroy all plant residue and regrowth after the season.
monitoring: Scout seedbeds and fields regularly, especially low-lying areas.
For Wildfire, look for pale-green spots that turn brown with a wide yellow halo.
For Angular Leaf Spot, look for necrotic, angular lesions without a halo.
Check for deformed or twisted young leaves.
direct_control: Remove and destroy infected seedlings and all others within a 1-meter radius; disinfect the area.
If the crop is severely affected, early harvesting can reduce losses.
Reap clean fields before infected ones to minimize spread.
In the seedbed, apply copper oxychloride at the collar level of seedlings or to foliage.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: In the nursery, it attacks senescent leaves and produces stem cankers. In the field, it causes beige to brown coloured leaf spots, sometimes concentric and surrounded by a yellow halo. It can also cause stem cankers after colonising defoliation wounds. A characteristic grey mould is produced on all attacked organs in favourable weather conditions.

prevention: Ensure good ventilation in nurseries to reduce humidity.
Avoid the presence of free water on plants.
Irrigate during the morning and early afternoon, not at night.
Manage nitrogen fertilisation to avoid succulent tissues or chlorotic leaves.
Disinfect shelter walls and equipment.
Eliminate plant debris rapidly.
monitoring: Monitor for stem cankers in nurseries.
Look for beige to brown leaf spots in the field.
Check for the characteristic grey mould on attacked organs.
direct_control: Use fungicides like iprodione or pyrimethanil, alternating between them.
If collar cankers are observed, ridging may promote adventitious root formation.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: The fungus colonises the plant roots, causing many brown to black lesions along the entire root length and destroying most of the feeder rootlets. A large proportion of the root system has a typical black rot. Affected plants are often poorly developed and chlorotic, and sometimes wilt in hot weather.

prevention: Use healthy substrates in the nursery.
Disinfect soil in traditional nurseries.
Use plastic film to separate mini-clods from the ground.
Apply hygienic measures.
Use long crop rotations (4-5 years) with non-sensitive crops like cereals, rice, and sorghum.
Clean tools and equipment after use in contaminated fields.
Ensure good field draining, fertilisation, and irrigation.
Maintain soil pH around 6.
Use resistant varieties.
monitoring: Monitor for poorly developed and chlorotic plants.
Check for wilting in hot weather.
Inspect roots for brown to black lesions and black rot.
direct_control: Remove diseased plants in the nursery.
Consider fungicide treatments (e.g., benzimidazoles, triadiménol) as a preventive measure or in specific contexts, but be aware of resistance risks.
Try ridging plants in the field to promote further rooting.
Destroy and remove tobacco stems and root systems from the field at the end of the season.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Causal Agents: Colletotrichum tabacum, Colletotrichum nicotianae, Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, Glomerella sp.
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Causes circular lesions that are initially dark and oily then become greyish, parchmentlike, and surrounded by a brown border. Some lateral veins may turn brown. Small elongated cankers are observed on petioles and stems, and sometimes these are covered by pink clusters of acervuli containing conidia.

prevention: Use disease-free seeds.
Manage plant debris and soil.
Avoid high humidity, cool temperatures, and low light.
monitoring: Monitor for circular lesions on leaves.
Check for cankers on petioles and stems.
direct_control: No product is approved for this use in France. Fungicide use may be an option in other regions.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Causal Agents: Golovinomyces cichoracearum var. cichoracearum, Erysiphe cichoracearum
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Greyish, white, felt-like powdery patches first appear on the upper leaf surface. They gradually spread and converge to cover the entire lamina. Afterwards the affected tissues show irregular brown lesions resulting from cell death.

prevention: Choose a plot location in a rather airy and sunny area.
Avoid excessive watering and stagnation of water in the plot.
Ensure a balanced fertilisation.
Destroy weeds in and around the plot.
Avoid the vicinity of crops that host the parasite.
Harvest the lower leaves as soon as possible.
Use resistant varieties.
monitoring: Monitor for greyish, white, felt-like powdery patches on the upper leaf surface.
Check for the spread of these patches and the appearance of irregular brown lesions.
direct_control: Apply chemical treatments early, such as with penconazole.
Apply treatments during cloudy and cool periods to avoid phytotoxicity.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Disease Name: Ragged leaf spot, Phoma leaf blight
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Causal Agents: Boeremia exigua var. exigua, Ascochyta nicotianae, Didymella sp.
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Causes irregular to circular, brown to ashy grey leaf spots. Occasionally, the spots are very large. Numerous pycnidia containing two-septate spores can be found scattered on these spots. Eventually the centre of the spot, which is dead tissue, disintegrates leaving a ragged appearing leaf.

prevention: Manage plant debris.
monitoring: Monitor for irregular to circular, brown to ashy grey leaf spots.
Check for pycnidia on the spots.
Look for ragged appearance of leaves as the center of the spot disintegrates.
direct_control: No product is registered for control of this disease in France.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Disease Name: Athelia stem rot, Southern stem rot
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Wet looking lesions develop on the stems at the soil level. They are often concave, light brown, rather dry in texture and sometimes surrounded by discrete concentric rings. Abundant white mycelium may cover the lesions and sometimes the soil close to the stem. Numerous small (1-3 mm), smooth and rather spherical sclerotia of the fungus may be observed. At first the sclerotia are white, but gradually turn brown as they mature.

prevention: Destruction of crop residues.
Soil disinfection.
Solarization.
Crop rotations.
monitoring: Look for wet looking lesions on the stems at the soil level.
Check for white mycelium on lesions and surrounding soil.
Look for small, spherical sclerotia that are initially white and turn brown.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Root systems are reduced in size. Large black lesions are found at the collar. The cortex shows deep splits in several locations.

prevention: Avoid growing other hosts of the pathogen, such as peanuts and soybeans, in rotation with tobacco.
monitoring: Check for reduced root systems.
Look for large black lesions at the collar.
Inspect the cortex for deep splits.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Rotting of the root cortex. The diseased tissue eventually turns pink. Dense, wine-coloured mycelia develops in the infected tissues, for instance the stem at the soil level.

monitoring: Check for rotting of the root cortex.
Look for pink discoloration of diseased tissue.
Check for dense, wine-coloured mycelia on the stem at the soil level.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Produces black lesions on the basal portion of the stem that frequently extend to the vessels and pith. These lesions are dotted with numerous smooth, black, and hard microsclerotia.

prevention: Destruction of crop residues.
Soil disinfection.
Crop rotation.
monitoring: Look for black lesions on the basal portion of the stem.
Check for microsclerotia on the lesions.
direct_control: No fungicide is registered in France to control this disease.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Associated with a widespread root browning of tobacco seedlings. In floating seedbeds severe root necrosis (or breakdown) may occur affecting the plant parts suspended in the nutrient solution. The affected plants grow slowly; they are chlorotic and sometimes wilt and dessicate.

prevention: In traditional nurseries, disinfection of the soil with a fumigant may be considered.
The addition of certain non-ionic wetters in the nutrient solution of floating seedbeds may partly eradicate the zoospores of Olpidium brassicae.
monitoring: Monitor for root browning and necrosis in seedlings.
Check for slow growth, chlorosis, wilting, and desiccation of plants.
direct_control: Eliminate heavily infected plants in traditional seedbeds.
In floating seedbeds, add water to the trays if the level has decreased.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: On seedlings, stem cankers are moist and light brown and tend to be covered with a dense white mycelium and very characteristic large black sclerotia. In the field, stem cankers are observed originating from defoliation wounds, pith invasion, and various forms of leaf rot.

prevention: Reduce nursery humidity by maximum ventilation.
Avoid sprinkler irrigation or use it during the hottest parts of the day.
Destroy infected plants and sclerotia.
Disinfect soil with a fumigant if outbreaks have occurred.
Ensure fields are well drained.
Plant healthy seedlings in fields that did not have crops sensitive to this fungus.
monitoring: Check for moist, light brown stem cankers on seedlings.
Look for dense white mycelium and large black sclerotia on cankers.
In the field, monitor for stem cankers and leaf rot.
direct_control: Remove sclerotia bearing seedlings and dead plants from nurseries.
Use fungicides in nurseries if outbreaks occur.
A biopesticide could be incorporated into the soil in areas of high risk.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: One to several leaves on infected plants turn yellow and dry up, usually on one side of the plant. A longitudinal section of the vessels reveals a homogeneous chocolate brown color. Occasionally young leaves and the bud area may be distorted.

prevention: Eliminate crop residues.
Clean farm equipment thoroughly before use in other fields.
Use long crop rotations that do not include susceptible hosts.
Use resistant varieties.
Control root-knot or cyst nematodes.
monitoring: Look for yellowing and drying of leaves, usually on one side of the plant.
Check for a homogeneous chocolate brown color in the vessels by making a longitudinal section.
Look for distortion of young leaves and the bud area.
direct_control: No control methods are currently available in France. In some countries, soaking the nursery soil with a solution of benomyl is recommended.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Wilting and/or a distinct yellowing affecting the lower leaves of tobacco plants, usually unilaterally. The infected lamina tissues later dry up. A longitudinal cut of the petioles of infected leaves and stem reveals that the vessels have turned yellowish to light brown.

prevention: Clean tools and equipment before use in other fields.
Use long crop rotations with non-susceptible crops like cereals.
Control weeds.
Consider soil disinfection with a fumigant or solarization in nurseries.
Flooding of contaminated plots may help limit the number of microsclerotia.
Use resistant varieties.
monitoring: Look for wilting and/or yellowing of lower leaves, often on one side of the plant.
Check for yellowish to light brown discoloration of vessels in petioles and stems.
direct_control: No control methods are currently available in France. Elimination of crop residues after harvest limits the inoculum source.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Disease Name: Black soft rot of stem and leaves, Hollow stalk
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Causal Agents: Pectobacterium spp., Erwinia spp., Pectobacterium carotovorum subsp. carotovorum, Pectobacterium chrysanthemi
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Infects young plants in nurseries causing a wet and black rot of seedlings at the soil line (black leg or soft rot). In the later growing season, the bacteria may penetrate the stem through topping wounds and cause a stem rot (hollow stalk). During curing, infected leaves develop a wet and black appearance as the rot spreads through the petiole and gradually progresses to the ribs and the inter-veinal tissues.

prevention: Avoid sprinkler irrigation whenever possible, or irrigate in the morning rather than in the evening.
Avoid topping or suckering by hand or mechanically during cloudy, wet days.
Disinfect seeds by soaking them for 12 minutes in hot water at 50°C or by treating them in a microwave for 20 minutes.
monitoring: Monitor for wet and black rot of seedlings at the soil line in nurseries.
Check for stem rot after topping.
Monitor for wet and black appearance of leaves during curing.
direct_control: Remove diseased seedlings from the nursery quickly.
Apply bacteriostatic solutions based on copper or cryptonol at the collar level of seedlings.
Lower the humidity level in the nursery.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Greasy spots appear on mature leaves. They turn brown and black and quite quickly show concentric rings. When the conditions are very favorable, large areas of the lamina are affected.

prevention: Avoid irrigation with sprinklers whenever possible, or irrigate in the morning rather than in the evening.
Use crop rotations of three years.
monitoring: Monitor for greasy spots on mature leaves that turn brown and black with concentric rings.
direct_control: Avoid hanging too damaged tobacco plants for curing.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Yellowing between the veins, most frequently on mature or intermediate leaves. The whole plant may gradually become yellow. Young shoots have a reduced growth, much shorter internodes, chlorotic leaves of reduced size with tips tending to curve down. Flowers are usually sterile and may show anomalies such as small size, enlarged calyx, and green colour of the petals.

prevention: Protect nursery plants with agrotextiles.
Careful weeding of nurseries, plots and their surroundings.
Do not place tobacco crops near other susceptible crops such as tomato, potato, pepper.
monitoring: Monitor for yellowing between the veins on mature or intermediate leaves.
Check for stunted growth, short internodes, and small, chlorotic, curved leaves on young shoots.
Inspect flowers for anomalies.
direct_control: There is no method to control phytoplasma during cultivation. If symptoms are observed in seedlings, they should not be planted.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Bright yellow mosaic (calico), spots, and rings on the leaves. Sometimes white necrotic patterns are observed. Leaf distortion and stunting of plants may also occur.

prevention: Control aphid populations.
Remove weed reservoirs around the fields.
Use healthy seedlings for planting.
monitoring: Monitor for bright yellow mosaic, spots, and rings on leaves.
Check for leaf distortion and stunting.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Young leaves are small, yellow, and curl upwards. Veins may appear translucent. Plants are generally stunted.

prevention: Control leafhopper vectors.
Manage weed hosts in and around the field.
monitoring: Monitor for small, yellow, upward-curling leaves.
Check for translucent veins and stunted plants.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Chlorotic rings and patterns on leaves, leaf distortion, and development of filiform (thread-like) leaves. Infected plants are stunted.

prevention: Control aphid populations, as they are the primary vectors.
Control measures are similar to those for Cucumber Mosaic Virus (CMV).
monitoring: Monitor for chlorotic rings, leaf distortion, and stunting.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Often asymptomatic. When symptoms are present, they typically include mild mottling and sometimes necrotic rings on the leaves.

prevention: Use virus-free seed or transplants.
Disinfect tools and hands regularly to prevent mechanical transmission.
monitoring: Monitor for mild mottling or necrotic rings, although plants may show no symptoms.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Causal Agents: Tobacco bushy top virus, often in complex with Tobacco vein distorting virus (TVDV)
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Shortened internodes and proliferation of axillary buds, which gives the plant a 'bushy top' appearance. Leaves are small, yellow, and may have necrotic spots.

prevention: Control aphid populations, which transmit the virus complex.
monitoring: Monitor for stunted, bushy plants with small, yellow leaves.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Mottling, chlorotic spots, and characteristic necrotic lines or 'etching' along the veins. Infected plants are often stunted.

prevention: Use resistant varieties if available.
Control aphid vectors.
Remove weed hosts from the vicinity of the crop.
monitoring: Monitor for mottling, chlorotic spots, and necrotic etching along veins.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Mosaic (light and dark green areas) and mottling on leaves, often accompanied by blistering, yellowing, and stunting. In hot weather, 'mosaic burn' (large necrotic areas) can occur.

prevention: Use resistant varieties.
Practice strict sanitation: wash hands with soap and water, and disinfect tools, especially when moving from one field to another.
Workers should avoid using tobacco products (cigarettes, snuff) while working with plants.
Soaking hands in non-fat milk can help inactivate the virus.
monitoring: Monitor for mosaic patterns, blistering, and stunting.
Be aware that symptoms can be variable.
direct_control: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to prevent spread.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Irregular, often circular and concentric lines on leaves. These lines are initially chlorotic and then become necrotic. They are often located along the veins. Infected plants are stunted.

prevention: Control nematode vectors (Xiphinema spp.) in the soil.
Eliminate weed reservoirs that can host the virus.
Disinfect tools to prevent mechanical transmission.
monitoring: Monitor for concentric, chlorotic, and necrotic rings on leaves.
Check for stunting of plants.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Leaves are curved and spoon-shaped, with spots, necrotic rings, and patterns. Leaf tissue has a brittle texture. Systemic necrotic lesions can be visible on the stem and leaves.

prevention: Control nematode vectors (Trichodorus and Paratrichodorus spp.).
monitoring: Monitor for curved, brittle leaves with necrotic rings and patterns.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Curling of younger leaves, vein chlorosis and necrosis, mottling, filiform leaves, shorter internodes, and stunting of plants.

prevention: The virus is transmitted by the soil fungus Olpidium brassicae, so management should focus on soil health and preventing pathogen spread.
monitoring: Monitor for a combination of stunting, leaf curling, and vein necrosis.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Brown necrotic spots appear near the veins, which may coalesce. Symptoms are mainly on lower leaves. Can cause death of young seedlings.

prevention: The virus is transmitted by the soil fungus Olpidium brassicae. Managing soil moisture and health is key.
monitoring: Monitor for brown necrotic spots on lower leaves.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Leaves are chlorotic, small, and tend to curve downward. Plant growth is significantly reduced, resulting in stunting.

prevention: Control the leafhopper vector (Orosius argentatus).
Control measures are similar to those for Stolbur.
monitoring: Monitor for small, yellow, downward-curling leaves and stunted plants.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Leaves are small, curled, and twisted. Enations (leafy outgrowths) may be present on the underside of the lamina along the veins. Plants are often stunted.

prevention: Control the whitefly vector (Bemisia tabaci).
Remove and destroy weed hosts.
Use resistant varieties if available.
monitoring: Monitor for small, curled, twisted leaves with potential enations.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Bands of dark green tissue along the veins (vein banding). Small white to brown spots can also be observed on the upper surface of younger leaves.

prevention: Control aphid vectors.
Control measures are similar to those for Cucumber Mosaic Virus (CMV).
monitoring: Monitor for dark green bands along veins.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Necrotic rings and patterns on leaves, often in connection with the veins. Young leaves can be necrotic, folded, and deformed.

prevention: Control thrips vectors.
Control measures are similar to those for Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus (TSWV).
monitoring: Monitor for necrotic rings and patterns on leaves.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Causal Agents: Alternaria alternata, Botrytis cinerea, Botryosporium spp., Rhizopus spp., Mucor spp., Sclerotinia sclerotiorum, Cladosporium spp., Fusarium spp., Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp., Pythium spp., Pseudomonas cichorii
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Various types of mould (grey, white, colored) and rot on leaves during air-curing, especially under high humidity conditions.

prevention: Ensure good ventilation in curing barns to manage temperature and moisture.
Avoid high humidity, which is favorable for the development of micro-organisms.
monitoring: Monitor leaves during the curing process for signs of mould and rot.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Causal Agents: Rhizopus spp., Mucor spp., Alternaria alternata, Botrytis cinerea, Sclerotinia sclerotiorum, Cercospora nicotianae, Gibberella tricincta, Pseudomonas syringae pv. angulata, Pectobacterium spp.
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Various types of mould and rot on leaves during flue-curing. Different micro-organisms are involved compared to air-curing due to higher temperatures.

prevention: Maintain precise control of moisture and temperature during the curing process.
Ensure curing temperatures range from 35 to 70°C as required.
monitoring: Monitor leaves for damage from micro-organisms, which can be different from those in air-curing.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Scientific Name: Carpocoris verbasci, Carpocoris lunula, Nezara viridula, Palomena prasina, Strachia oleracea, Lygus spp.
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Characteristic Visual Damage: Total or partial wilting of leaves, which may turn yellow and necrotic. Lamina deformations and curling can occur after a bug bite on the midrib.

monitoring: Monitor for wilting, yellowing, and necrotic leaves.
Check for lamina deformations.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Scientific Name: Conocephalus mandibulasis, Lacusta viridissima, Manduca sexta, Manduca quemanculata, Popillia japonica
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Characteristic Visual Damage: Consumption of significant portions of the lamina. With high pest populations, only midribs may remain.

monitoring: Monitor for holes in leaves and defoliation.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Scientific Name: Agriotes spp., Melolontha melolontha, Korscheltellus lupulinus, Forficula auricularia, Deroceras reticulatum, Gryllotalpa gryllotalpa, Neocurtilla sp.
fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Characteristic Visual Damage: Damage varies by pest, but can include emptying of the stem, perforation and cutting of the stem at the soil level, consumption of roots, and cutting of leaves.

monitoring: Monitor for various types of damage to roots, stems, and leaves.

fungal_and_bacterial_diseases.Characteristic Visual Damage: Larvae make galleries in piles of tobacco leaves. Adult beetles emerge from pupal chambers by making small holes to the outside.

monitoring: Monitor for galleries and holes in stored tobacco leaves.

major_insect_pests.Scientific Name: Heliothis virescens, Helicoverpa armigera, Spodoptera litura
major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Larvae feed on top tender leaves and developing buds, creating holes in expanding leaves. They can also cut the stems of seedlings or feed on leaf tissues along the veins. They destroy flowers and seed capsules.

prevention: Adjust planting date to avoid seasonal peaks of pest populations.
Plant trap crops (e.g., maize, okra, sunflower, taro) around tobacco and destroy them before larvae pupate.
Deep ploughing to expose pupae to predators and environmental conditions.
Remove and destroy crop residues and volunteer plants.
Avoid crop rotation with other host plants like soybeans, cotton, and corn.
Timely topping will prevent the build-up of budworm populations.
monitoring: Monitor for pests and symptoms 1-2 times per week from emergence to harvest.
Use pheromone traps to detect early adult moth populations.
Look for egg masses (often covered with brown hair scales for Spodoptera) or single eggs on tender shoots and flowers.
Identify larvae by their characteristic bands and colors.
Check for feeding damage on buds and leaves.
direct_control: Handpick and destroy egg masses and larvae.
Release natural enemies like Trichogramma, Telenomus, or Cotesia species if available.
Place baited traps (5/ha) with sex pheromones to monitor and catch adults.
Plough the soil after harvesting to expose pupae.
Apply appropriate insecticides like flubendiamide, spinosad, or indoxacarb, following all label directions for timing and safety.

major_insect_pests.Scientific Name: Peridroma saucia, Agrotis ipsilon, Xestia c-nigrum
major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Small larvae cause small holes on young leaves. Larger larvae cut the stem at the soil level at night, causing transplants to fall over.

prevention: Avoid planting in fields with a known history of cutworm problems.
Practice early planting.
Prepare the soil 4 to 6 weeks before transplanting.
Control weeds and grass in and around fields to destroy overwintering sites.
Remove crop residue and plough the soil after harvest to expose larvae and pupae.
Encourage natural enemies by planting conservation strips.
Rotate planting sites and/or crops.
monitoring: Scout in the evening for larvae or their damage during the first 3-4 weeks after transplanting.
Identify larvae: greyish to dark brown, up to 5 cm long, hide curled up in the soil by day.
Look for small, webless holes from small larvae and cut stems from larger larvae.
Use larval bait traps and adult pheromone traps to monitor populations.
Take control measures when 5% of newly transplanted plants are attacked.
direct_control: During scouting, handpick and destroy larvae found.
Release natural enemies such as Cotesia spp. or tachinid flies (Linnaemya comta).
Apply appropriate insecticides like Indoxacarb or Beauveria bassiana, following all label directions.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Infestations cause stunting and reduced yields. Leaves become thinner, black, and stuck together due to the growth of sooty mold on excreted honeydew.

prevention: Practice early planting, as it is less favorable to aphids.
Avoid excessive rates of nitrogen fertilizer.
Top plants at the 50% button or early flower stage to eliminate food sources.
Control weeds around seedbeds and fields.
Practice good sucker control to reduce food sources.
Encourage natural enemies (ladybirds, lacewings, hoverflies) by reducing insecticide use and maintaining flowering plants.
Destroy overwintering hosts like wild mustard near greenhouses.
Avoid growing alternative hosts (tomato, potato) near tobacco fields.
monitoring: Monitor once a week for aphids or their damage, beginning 3-4 weeks after transplanting.
Look on the underside of upper leaves for aphid colonies (both red and green forms).
Check upper surfaces of middle and lower leaves for sticky honeydew or black sooty mold.
Take control measures when 50 or more aphids are found on any upper leaf of 10% of the monitored plants.
direct_control: Release parasitoids such as Aphidius colemani if available.
Use yellow sticky traps to control winged aphids.
Apply Neem-based products (e.g., NeemAzal-T/S or AzaMax).
Topping can be used to reduce aphid populations as it increases leaf thickness and alkaloid concentrations.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Heavy infestations cause yellowing, curling, and crumpling of leaves. Whiteflies excrete honeydew, leading to sooty mold. They are major vectors for viruses like Tobacco Leaf Curl Virus.

prevention: Remove and destroy tobacco residues and volunteer plants after harvest.
Use resistant varieties if available.
Use shade nets or tunnels in the nursery.
Cover greenhouse vents with netting.
Transplant shortly after or during the rainy season.
Use white/black plastic mulch to attract and kill whiteflies.
Conserve natural enemies by leaving a hedge of flowering plants.
Plant repellent crops like coriander or marigold.
Keep fields weed-free, as weeds are alternate hosts.
Avoid planting near other host crops like tomato, pepper, or cassava.
monitoring: Monitor weekly until harvest, especially on the underside of leaves.
Adults (1mm, white, powdery) will fly when plants are shaken.
Look for yellow-white larvae (scales) and brown pupae.
Check for yellowing, curling leaves and sooty mold.
Use yellow sticky traps to detect adults.
Take action if 3-5 whiteflies are found per plant 7-14 days after transplanting.
direct_control: Use yellow sticky traps (1 per 5 plants).
Conserve and release natural enemies like Encarsia and Eretmocerus wasps, ladybirds, and lacewing larvae.
Spray with natural fatty acid or soap products.
Apply Beauveria bassiana or appropriate insecticides like Imidacloprid, following all label directions.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Above ground: plants are stunted, yellow, and wilt during the hottest hours of the day. Flowering may be premature, delayed, or suppressed. Below ground: presence of knots or galls on the roots.

prevention: Use resistant varieties.
Use floating seedbed systems to protect trays from contamination.
Disinfect nursery soil using solarization.
Prepare raised beds to reduce nematode impact.
Practice early planting.
Maintain strict weed control during and between seasons.
Ensure good fertilization and irrigation.
Plant cover crops or trap crops and disk under before nematode reproduction occurs.
Practice crop rotation with non-hosts like small grains and fescue for at least four years.
Clean and disinfect tools and equipment used in contaminated fields.
monitoring: Monitor for symptoms in nurseries and fields until harvest.
Look for stunted, yellow, wilting plants.
Inspect roots for the presence of knots or galls.
Collect soil samples at the end of the season to identify nematode species and plan for the next year.
direct_control: If outbreaks occur in nurseries, affected plants should be removed.
At the end of the season, destroy and remove root systems from the field (or expose them to dry up).
In some cases, flooding contaminated fields for 7 to 9 months can control nematodes.
Make green manure with Crotalaria. Do not plant beans, soybeans, or other legumes in the same area.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Causes slow and stunted growth, especially in new growth and seedlings. Leaves show silvery outlines traced around the veins, may become yellow, crinkled, and cup upward. Small black spots (excrement) may be visible on the underside of leaves.

prevention: Regularly weed the plot and field borders at least two weeks before transplanting.
Avoid planting near grain and alfalfa fields.
Plant younger fields upwind from older fields.
If possible, plant during the rainy season when populations are low.
Keep the crop healthy with good water and fertilizer management.
Use ultraviolet-reflective mulch to repel thrips.
Conserve habitat for natural enemies like the minute pirate bug (Orius insidiosus).
monitoring: Monitor leaf surfaces in the first 3-4 weeks after transplanting (may need a hand lens).
Look for adults (pale yellow to brown/black, 1-2 mm long) and larvae (whitish-yellowish).
Watch for silvery outlines on veins, crinkled leaves, and small black spots.
Monitor closely during hot, arid weather.
Use yellow or white sticky traps to monitor adults.
direct_control: After harvest, remove or destroy volunteer tobacco plants and debris.
Apply appropriate insecticides like imidacloprid, spinosad, acetamiprid, or thiamethoxam in the seedbed or field, following all label directions.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Chews holes in the leaves. Damage is most common from 6 weeks after transplanting to final harvest.

prevention: Regularly remove weeds and tall grass from adjacent land to reduce breeding sites.
Avoid controlling weeds or haying immediately before and for 4 weeks after transplanting, as this can drive grasshoppers into the tobacco field.
Encourage habitat for natural enemies (spiders, robber flies, birds, etc.).
Tilling the land before and after the season can expose eggs to weather and predators.
monitoring: Monitor for adult grasshoppers (up to 5 cm, slender, large hind legs) and smaller, wingless nymphs.
Look for holes in the leaves.
Monitor closely during hot, dry years when populations are higher.
Take action when there are 10 or more grasshoppers per 50 plants.
direct_control: Apply neem to foliage when pests first appear, making 2-3 applications at 7-10 day intervals.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Internal feeding by the small, whitish caterpillar causes stem galls, sprouted side branches, and stunted, distorted, and withered plants.

prevention: Grow seedlings in greenhouses with appropriate netting.
Avoid establishing new fields near old, heavily infested ones.
Avoid planting near or rotating with aubergine (eggplant), another host.
Plant wildflowers (e.g., Tagetes spp.) and sorghum to attract natural enemies.
Conserve parasitoids and predators by avoiding unnecessary insecticide sprays.
After harvest, uproot and burn plant residues to kill remaining larvae and pupae.
Remove solanaceous weeds from the seedbed and field.
monitoring: Begin scouting 7 days after transplanting, observing young plants twice a week for eggs and larvae.
Look for small, whitish caterpillars with dark brown heads and thoraxes.
Check for stem galls and distorted growth.
Take action when 3-10% of young plants are damaged.
direct_control: Handpick and crush larvae during early scouting.
Remove and destroy affected seedlings.
Install solar light traps to catch nocturnal adults.
Spray with solutions of Beauveria bassiana or baculoviruses.
Apply appropriate insecticides like flubendiamide or indoxacarb, following all label directions.

major_insect_pests.Pest Common Name: Chrysanthemum foliar nematode, Checkered leaf disease
major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Causes large polygonal spots on the leaves which are first light green to yellow, then turn to brown or black, giving the leaves the appearance of a checkerboard.

prevention: Remove plant debris during and at the end of the crop to avoid the survival of the nematode in the soil.
Disinfect shelters carefully if they will be used to produce seedlings.
Control weeds, as the nematode is hosted by a large number of them.
monitoring: Monitor for large, polygonal, discolored spots on leaves.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Newly developed leaves grow asymmetrically and are 'twisted'. The cortical tissue at the collar level is swollen and distorted, and can decompose, leading to stem breakage.

prevention: Promptly remove and destroy stems at the end of the season.
Choose crop rotations carefully, avoiding susceptible crops like beets.
monitoring: Monitor for asymmetrical and twisted new leaves.
Check for swollen and distorted tissue at the collar.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Produces cysts on the roots that are first white and then gradually darken. The root system shows numerous brown lesions and reduced growth. Affected plants show restricted development and wilt during the hottest periods of the day.

prevention: Many methods for managing Meloidogyne spp. can also be used to control Globodera spp.
monitoring: Monitor for white to dark cysts on the roots.
Check for brown lesions and reduced growth of the root system.
Look for stunted plants that wilt in the heat.

major_insect_pests.Characteristic Visual Damage: Causes lesions of varying size on the roots, with colors from yellowish to reddish-brown or black. Portions of the cortex decay, and in severe cases, a large proportion of the root system may disappear. Plants are stunted, may turn yellow, and wilt on hot days.

prevention: Choose crop rotations carefully due to the wide host range of these nematodes.
Varieties resistant to Meloidogyne incognita may show some resistance.
monitoring: Monitor for lesions on the roots.
Check for stunted, yellowing, and wilting plants.

weeds_and_parasitic_plants.Primary Visual Symptoms: Erect, perennial sedge (30-60 cm high) with an extensive underground network of dark, irregular-shaped tubers. Leaves are linear with a distinct midrib. Flowering stems are 3-sided, with purplish-brown flowerheads.
Key Plant Parts Affected: Competes with whole plant for resources.

prevention: Clean tools and farm machinery to prevent spreading tubers.
Do not use potentially contaminated materials like soil on planting stock.
Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding.
Plant cover crops like alfalfa to suppress establishment.
monitoring: Regularly inspect fields (at least bi-weekly), particularly in low spots, wetlands, and along waterways, especially during wet weather.
Look for the characteristic 3-sided stem and purplish-brown flowerheads.
direct_control: Use nursery soil solarization with plastic sheeting for two weeks to kill tubers.
Destroy tubers and rhizomes by ploughing and exposing them to sunlight to desiccate them; most effective in dry soil.
Place organic mulch over areas to provide temporary suppression.
Conduct fortnightly spot weeding as necessary.
Apply appropriate herbicides like Clomazone or Fluazifop-P-butyl, following all label directions.

weeds_and_parasitic_plants.Primary Visual Symptoms: The parasite gradually colonises the tobacco plant by its voluble, leafless stems. On the stems, there are haustoria that enable dodder to absorb nutrients from its host. Dodder also has clusters of small flowers with different colours depending on the species (white, yellow, pink).

prevention: Use crop rotations with non-host plants.
Use herbicides against pre-emergence.
monitoring: Monitor for voluble, leafless stems colonising the tobacco plant.

weeds_and_parasitic_plants.Primary Visual Symptoms: This plant produces neither roots nor chlorophyll and parasitises the roots of tobacco. It first occurs in summer by the appearance of flowering spikes from fifteen to forty centimeters in height. These flower spikes have pale-blue to purplish-blue flowers.

prevention: Avoid short rotations with known host crops (e.g., colza).
Manage weeds, as many are also hosts.
Clean tools carefully after use in an infested plot.
monitoring: Monitor for the appearance of flowering spikes near tobacco plants.
Look for growth abnormalities (yellowing, stunting) in cases of severe infestation.
direct_control: Use soil tools after harvest to separate the broomrape from tobacco before it seeds.
Apply appropriate herbicides.
Plant a trap crop (e.g., colza, mustard) and destroy it before the parasite can produce seeds.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Reduction in seedling growth, yellowing, browning along the leaf blade, and drying up. Can be caused by excessive irrigation, high calcium bicarbonate in water, poor mineral content, or high concentration of soluble salts.

prevention: Ensure proper irrigation.
Use water with balanced mineral content.
Avoid excessive use of pesticides.
monitoring: Monitor for reduced growth and discoloration of leaves.
direct_control: Several consecutive waterings over the top can solve problems related to high soluble salts.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Modified habit, colour and shape of some of its organs. Examples include 'ruffle leaf' (leaves curved downward, some with only a midrib), 'toad-skin' (dark green leaves with protrusions), and 'leaf curl' (leaves rolled upward).

prevention: Breeders should avoid introducing these abnormalities into cultivated genotypes.
monitoring: Monitor for plants with unusual growth habits or leaf shapes.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Sudden wilting of plants after heavy rain or waterlogging. The lamina turns more or less yellow and then dries up. In severe cases, plants may wilt and completely dry up.

prevention: Ensure fields are well-drained.
Plant tobacco on relatively high ridges.
Avoid heavy soils.
monitoring: Monitor for wilting and yellowing of plants after heavy rain.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Wide parts of tissues turning brown and gradually drying up on some growing tobacco leaves, particularly exposed to sunlight during periods of extreme heat. Leaves are very succulent and may partially wilt and dry up, especially on the leaf margins and at the tip.

monitoring: Monitor for browning and drying of leaves during hot weather.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Corky lesions at the base of the tobacco stem. Slight chlorosis and wilting of plants during the hottest periods of the day, a slowdown in growth. Suberisation and collar rot and taproot that have more or less important bursts.

prevention: Avoid agricultural practices causing water stagnation.
monitoring: Monitor for chlorosis, wilting, and corky lesions on the collar.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Holes, splits, and localised necrotic lesions on leaves, stems and inflorescences, corresponding to the points of impact. Some leaves can be completely shredded.

monitoring: Monitor for physical damage to plants after hailstorms.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Affected young leaves are partially or completely translucent and tend to become spoon-shaped. Subsequently, affected leaves may be distorted and show discolorations.

prevention: Protect seedlings from cold, as tobacco is a plant of tropical origin.
monitoring: Monitor for translucent, spoon-shaped, and discolored leaves on seedlings.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Symptoms vary depending on the deficient nutrient, but often include yellowing, chlorosis, and necrosis on leaves, as well as stunting and deformation. Symptoms can appear on lower or younger leaves depending on the nutrient.

prevention: Ensure balanced fertilization based on soil tests.
monitoring: Monitor for discoloration and deformation of leaves.
Consult a specialist and carry out soil and vegetation analyses if deficiencies are suspected.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Adventitious roots gradually appear on tobacco plant stems. One can first observe the development of many isolated protrusions along the stem. They will later open, giving birth to a very short root, a primordium.

prevention: Ensure the root system and stem are in good condition, as this phenomenon can be a marker of plant malfunction.
monitoring: Monitor for the appearance of adventitious roots on the stem.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Longitudinal stem splits in a few tobacco plants. They often reflect an excess of plant vigour which may occur especially after a climatic and water stress.

monitoring: Monitor for longitudinal splits in the stem.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Flattening and broadening of the stem, which tends to be grooved (fasciation). Superficial moist lesions on the midrib, the stem and occasionally the flower spikes, that first turn grey-brown and are later covered with cracks.

prevention: Breeders should be careful when doing crosses, as these flaws are easily passed on to offspring.
monitoring: Monitor for flattened, grooved stems and lesions on various plant parts.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Circular areas in tobacco fields that suddenly wilt. Leaves are distorted, their midribs and veins are often brown and necrotic, and interveinal tissues tend to become necrotic. The stem is also injured and it may have superficial brown lesions. The pith shrinks and takes the appearance of several stacked discs.

monitoring: Monitor for circular areas of wilting plants after a storm.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Various lesions on cured leaves, such as green spots, greenish tissues, dark or greyish colors, and browning or blackening of tissues adjacent to veins. These are caused by issues during cultivation, harvesting, or curing.

prevention: Ensure good quality of leaves at harvest.
Handle leaves carefully during harvest.
Manage curing conditions properly.
monitoring: Monitor for lesions on leaves during and after curing.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Symptoms vary widely but can include yellowing, bleaching, spotting, and deformation of leaves, as well as changes in plant habit. The distribution of symptoms can be general or localized depending on the source of the injury.

prevention: Use pesticides and herbicides at appropriate doses and stages of plant growth.
Rinse treatment equipment thoroughly.
Be aware of the potential for herbicide residues in the soil.
monitoring: Monitor for unusual symptoms after pesticide or herbicide application.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Marked yellowing of interveinal tissues, with veins remaining green. New leaves are slender, with the tip curled down and wavy edges. Proliferation of axillary buds gives the plant a 'witches broom' appearance.

prevention: Drain the plot to avoid excessive moisture.
Avoid excessive intake of soil alkalising elements.
Ensure balanced fertilisation.
monitoring: Monitor for yellowing of interveinal tissues and abnormal leaf shape.
direct_control: Soil disinfection usually results in control of this problem in nursery.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: In France, the name 'rust' is frequently improperly used to designate brown spots, often of physiological nature. For more information, see 'Pollution spots (weather fleck)'.
The root system of tobacco commonly presents a very shallow configuration. The impermeable pan can induce waterlogging, causing alteration and browning of roots and wilting of the plant.

prevention: Avoid soil cultivation in bad conditions.
monitoring: Monitor for shallow root systems and wilting plants.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Wet, then brown, isolated or confluent spots on the underside of tobacco leaves, sometimes localised along the veins. The spots lighten quite rapidly.

monitoring: Monitor for wet, brown spots on the underside of leaves.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Many small spots, located mostly on the upper side of lamina, sometimes contiguous and located along the midrib and secondary veins. Their colour changes over time and turns fairly quickly from brown at first, to greyish white afterwards.

prevention: Grow least sensitive varieties in areas where air pollution is high.
monitoring: Monitor for small, discolored spots on the upper side of leaves.

non_parasitic_diseases.Primary Visual Symptoms: Red-brown necrosis between the veins of the lower leaves of tobacco plants. Often occurs simultaneously in several fields of the same production area.

monitoring: Monitor for red-brown necrosis on lower leaves.
